Learning Objectives

By engaging with this resource, Äkonga (students) will:

  • Understand the key requirements for NCEA Level 1 Literacy and Numeracy standards
  • Develop strategies for culturally responsive assessment preparation
  • Apply literacy and numeracy skills across different learning contexts
  • Recognize how tikanga MÄori (MÄori customs) can support learning success
  • Create a personalized study plan that honors their cultural identity

Cultural Context: Te Ao MÄori Perspectives

Success in NCEA assessments can be supported by understanding and applying MÄori cultural concepts:

  • Whanaungatanga - Build study groups with peers to support each other
  • Manaakitanga - Show respect for yourself and others in your preparation
  • Ako - Recognize that learning is reciprocal; teach others to strengthen your own understanding
  • Tuakana-teina - Older/more experienced students can guide younger ones

Tikanga Considerations: When preparing for assessments, consider how you can bring your whole self to the process. This might include:

  • Starting with a karakia (prayer) to focus your mind
  • Creating study spaces that reflect your cultural identity
  • Using MÄori metaphors for learning (e.g., viewing knowledge as a kete - basket to be filled)

Literacy Must-Knows

Key Skills Checklist

  • I can identify the main ideas and supporting details in texts
  • I can write clear, structured responses to questions
  • I can use appropriate vocabulary for different subjects
  • I can proofread my work for spelling, grammar, and clarity
  • I can interpret visual information (graphs, diagrams, etc.)

Tip: Click the boxes above as you master each skill!

Literacy Across Subjects

Subject Literacy Focus Example
English Analyzing texts, writing essays Comparing themes across novels
Science Writing lab reports, reading scientific articles Describing an experiment's methodology
Social Studies Interpreting historical sources, constructing arguments Evaluating perspectives on a current issue
Mathematics Understanding word problems, explaining reasoning Justifying your solution to a problem

Numeracy Must-Knows

Key Skills Checklist

  • I can solve problems using basic operations (+, -, Ã—, Ã·)
  • I can work with fractions, decimals, and percentages
  • I can interpret graphs, tables, and charts
  • I can measure and calculate using appropriate units
  • I can apply mathematical reasoning to real-world situations

Numeracy in Real Life

Numeracy isn't just for math class! Here's where you use these skills:

  • Science: Calculating concentrations, analyzing data
  • Social Studies: Interpreting population statistics
  • PE/Health: Calculating heart rates, nutrition percentages
  • Technology: Measuring materials, scaling designs
  • Everyday Life: Budgeting, measuring ingredients, comparing prices

Assessment Rubric: Literacy & Numeracy Skills

Criteria Achieved Merit Excellence
Understanding Basic comprehension of texts/problems Clear understanding with some connections made Insightful understanding with sophisticated connections
Application Basic application of skills Effective application in familiar contexts Skilled application in new contexts
Communication Simple, mostly clear communication Clear, structured communication Precise, well-crafted communication
Ako (Learning) Shows basic reflection on learning Demonstrates thoughtful learning strategies Shows sophisticated, independent learning approaches

Extension Activities

Choose Your Challenge

  • Literacy: Create a pÅ«rÄkau (story) that explains a math concept using MÄori cultural references
  • Numeracy: Analyze statistical data about MÄori achievement in NCEA and present your findings
  • Integrated: Design a wharenui (meeting house) using scale drawings and write instructions for its construction
  • Community: Interview a kaumÄtua (elder) about traditional MÄori measurement systems and compare to modern methods

Teacher Implementation Notes

Curriculum Links: This resource supports achievement of NCEA Level 1 Literacy and Numeracy standards across all learning areas of the New Zealand Curriculum.

Suggested Use:

  • Print as a workbook for students to complete over several weeks
  • Use sections as starter activities in different subject classes
  • Assign the extension activities as group projects
  • Incorporate the cultural elements into existing assessment preparation

Differentiation Strategies:

  • Provide MÄori-English dictionaries for vocabulary support
  • Allow students to complete some tasks in te reo MÄori
  • Offer multiple ways to demonstrate understanding (oral, visual, written)
  • Pair students using tuakana-teina (mentoring) approach

Resources & References

  • NZQA Literacy and Numeracy Requirements: www.nzqa.govt.nz
  • Te Kete Ipurangi (TKI) Literacy Resources: literacyonline.tki.org.nz
  • Numeracy Project Resources: nzmaths.co.nz
  • Te Whanake MÄori Language Resources: www.tewhanake.maori.nz
  • MÄori Dictionary: maoridictionary.co.nz
